Based on Eq. ( 2a), the RRC was estimated from the regression slope of R on T by using satellite observations (Fig. 5a) and the CMIP5-model outputs (Fig. 5b–p) under the assumption that any TOA radiation changes (red) were largely a response to the temperature (black) in the Arctic region. We applied monthly time-dependent perturbations to estimate a reliable RRC over the Arctic region. If time-dependent perturbations with short time scales (a few hours to days) were applied, some of R’s response to T may not have excluded long-term feedback processes, such as the ice-albedo feedback. Similarly, time-dependent perturbations with long time scales (over a month) may have included an equilibration effect of R
34, 35 . Next, we took 12-month moving averages over monthly anomalous time series to exclude any non-feedback factors (e.g., strong seasonality and autonomous cloud variations) while retaining any radiative-feedback processes with time spans longer than a month, such as the ice-albedo feedback process
56 . If the 12-month moving average was not taken, non-feedback factors would have made the radiative response unstable
20 .
